masters.name: Elon Musk
key_principles: First principles thinking: Boil things down to fundamental truths and reason up from there.
If something is important enough, you do it even if the odds are not in your favor.
Failure is an option here. If things are not failing, you are not innovating enough.
Work like hell. 80-100 hour weeks every week.
When something is important enough, you do it even if the odds are not in your favor.
Constantly think about how you could be doing things better.
daily_practices: Work on the hardest problem first

masters.name: Jeff Bezos
masters.expertise: Long-term thinking, customer obsession, Day 1 mentality
key_principles: Focus on customers, not competitors.
It's always Day 1. Day 2 is stasis, followed by death.
Make high-velocity decisions. Most decisions are reversible.
Invent on behalf of customers. They won't tell you what they need.
Your margin is my opportunity.
If you never want to be criticized, for goodness' sake don't do anything new.
daily_practices: Start with the customer and work backwards
Make decisions with 70% of information needed

masters.name: Peter Thiel
masters.expertise: Contrarian thinking, monopolies, zero to one
key_principles: Competition is for losers. Build a monopoly.
The best investment in a portfolio equals or outperforms the rest combined.
What important truth do very few people agree with you on?
Going from 0 to 1 is harder and more valuable than 1 to N.
A startup messed up at its foundation cannot be fixed.
The most contrarian thing is not to oppose the crowd but to think for yourself.
daily_practices: Ask: What's a belief I hold that most people disagree with?
Build something 10x better, not incrementally better
Focus resources on the one thing that matters most

masters.name: Paul Graham
key_principles: Make something people want.
Launch fast and iterate.
Talk to users. Build what they need.
Do things that don't scale in the beginning.
The best founders have a chip on their shoulder.
If you're not embarrassed by your first version, you launched too late.
daily_practices: Talk to at least one user/customer today
Focus on making something people actually want

masters.name: Sam Altman
key_principles: Compounding is magic. Long-term thinking wins.
It's easier to do a hard startup than an easy startup.
The most important thing is to build something people want.
Great execution is at least 10x more important than a great idea.
Hire slowly, fire quickly.
Focus is a force multiplier.
daily_practices: Make yourself a force multiplier for your team

daily_insights: Ideas are worth nothing. Execution is everything.
The best time to start was yesterday. The second best time is now.
If you're not embarrassed by your first version, you launched too late.
Talk to customers before building. Validate before investing.
Revenue solves all problems. Get to revenue fast.
Your competition is irrelevant. Focus on your customer.
Speed is a feature. Move fast, break things, learn faster.
The best business moats are built on skills others can't copy.
Great businesses solve painful problems for people who can pay.
Think in decades, act in days.
skill_challenges: Validate one business idea by talking to 3 potential customers.
Use ICE scoring on 3 ideas. Pick the highest score to explore.
Write a one-page business model for an idea you have.
Find a problem people complain about. Brainstorm 3 solutions.
Research one successful business in your space. What can you learn?
Calculate the unit economics of a business idea.
Send one cold email to someone you want to learn from.
Identify the 20% of features that would deliver 80% of value.
Map out the minimum viable version of your best idea.
Set a 30-day sprint goal for one project. Write it down.
